sen.j: 唐名（とうめい、とうみょう、からな）は、律令制日本の律令制下の官職名・部署名を同様の職掌を持つ中国の官称にあてはめたもの。
sen.e: Tang name (tomei, tomyo, or karana) is Chinese names of the government posts which were adopted to names of the government posts and departments, which official duties were similar, under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

Tang names (tomei, tomyo, or karana) are Chinese names of government posts or departments each of which corresponds to a Japanese name of a government post or department whose official duties were similar to those of Tang under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: Tang names (tomei, tomyo, or karana) are Chinese names of government posts or departments each of which corresponds to a Japanese name of a government post or department whose official duties were similar to those of Tang under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

sen.j: 8世紀前半、大宝律令・養老律令により日本の官制律令制（大宝律令）以後以下の職制が整備され、百官の職名が制定されていった。
sen.e: In the early eighth century, in accordance with Taiho Ritsuryo Code and Yoro Ritsuryo Code, the office organizations, which are described below, after the establishment of the government-regulated ritsuryo system (Taiho Ritsuryo Code) were developed, and official titles of all the officials were established.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the early eighth century, in accordance with Taiho Ritsuryo Code and Yoro Ritsuryo Code, the office organizations, as described below, after the establishment of the government-regulated ritsuryo system (Taiho Ritsuryo Code), were developed and official titles of all the officials were established.
sen.cmt: which are described below をas described belowに変更、were developed, and official titles を,were developed and official titles に変更しました。
sen.e: In the early eighth century, in accordance with Taiho Ritsuryo Code and Yoro Ritsuryo Code, the office organizations, as described below, after the establishment of the government-regulated ritsuryo system (Taiho Ritsuryo Code), were developed and official titles of all the officials were established.

sen.j: その前後からすでに、同様の職掌を有する唐風の職名および部署名を一種の雅称として用いることが行われていたが、唐風文化に心酔する藤原仲麻呂が政権を握ると、天平宝字2年（758年）百官名をすべて唐名で言い換えることが行われた。
sen.e: Around that time, Tang-style official titles and department names representing the similar official duties were already used as a kind of elegant names, and when FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, who idolized the Tang culture, took control of the government, the titles of all the officials were translated into Tang names in 758.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Around that time, Tang-style official titles and department names representing the same official duties were already used as a kind of elegant name, and when FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, who idolized the Tang culture, took control of the government, the titles of all the officials were translated into Tang names in 758.
sen.cmt: the similar official duties --> the same official duties,as a kind of elegant names --> as a kind of elegant name
sen.e: Around that time, Tang-style official titles and department names representing the same official duties were already used as a kind of elegant name, and when FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, who idolized the Tang culture, took control of the government, the titles of all the officials were translated into Tang names in 758.

sen.j: （仲麻呂自らは新設した紫微中台＝皇太后宮職として紫微令を称した。）
sen.e: (Nakamaro himself had taken the title Shibirei [director general of Shibi institution] of the newly created Shibi chudai [office handling the principal empress Komyo's affairs], namely kotaigogushoku [Imperial Household Agency officer assigned to the household of Queen Mother])
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (Nakamaro himself had taken the title Shibirei [director general of Shibi institution] of the newly created Shibi chudai [office handling the principal empress Komyo's affairs], namely kotaigogushoku [Imperial Household Agency officer assigned to the household of Queen Mother])

(Nakamaro himself had taken the title Shibirei [director general of Shibi institution] of the newly created Shibi chudai [office handling the principal empress Komyo's affairs], namely kotaigogushoku [Imperial Household Agency officer assigned to the household of Queen Mother])

sen.j: 天平宝字8年（764年）仲麻呂失脚後は旧に戻されたが、その後も官職の別名・雅称として用いられることが多かった。
sen.e: After Nakamaro fell from the position in 764, the titles were returned to the former names, however, the Tang name was often used as another name or an elegant name of the government post.
After Nakamaro fell from the position in 764, the titles were returned to the former names, however, the Tang name was often used as another name or an elegant name of the government post.
After Nakamaro fell from the position in 764, the titles were returned to the former names, however, the Tang name was often used as another name or an elegant name of the government post.

sen.j: 奈良時代後半から平安時代にかけて生じた様々な令外官についても、唐名がつけられた。
sen.e: Various Ryoge no kan (posts outside the original Ritsuryo code created by Imperial edicts), which were created from the late Nara period to the Heian period, had Tang names.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Various Ryoge no kan (posts outside the original Ritsuryo code created by Imperial edicts), which were created from the late Nara period to the Heian period, had Tang names.
Various Ryoge no kan (posts outside the original Ritsuryo code created by Imperial edicts), which were created from the late Nara period to the Heian period, had Tang names.

sen.j: （蔵人頭・検非違使などの令外官を置いた嵯峨天皇も唐風文化の心酔者であった。）
sen.e: (The Emperor Saga who set the posts of Ryoge no kan such as Kurodo no to [Head Chamberlain] and kebiishi [officials with judicial and police powers] also idolized the Tang culture.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (The Emperor Saga who set the posts of Ryoge no kan such as Kurodo no to [Head Chamberlain] and kebiishi [officials with judicial and police powers] also idolized the Tang culture.)
(The Emperor Saga who set the posts of Ryoge no kan such as Kurodo no to [Head Chamberlain] and kebiishi [officials with judicial and police powers] also idolized the Tang culture.)

sen.j: これらの唐名は、本家中国歴代王朝の職制と完全に一致するわけではないため、必ずしも一対一で置換ができるものではない。
sen.e: These Tang names do not completely match with the office organizations in Chinese successive dynasties which were the originator of such organizations, so that they cannot be always replaced by one-to-one correspondence.
These Tang names do not completely match the office organizations originated in Chinese successive dynasties, so that they cannot be always replaced by one-to-one correspondence.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: These Tang names do not completely match the office organizations originated in Chinese successive dynasties, so that they cannot be always replaced by one-to-one correspondence.

sen.j: そのためいくつかの職においては重複するものあり、逆にひとつの職に対し複数の唐名があるものも少なくない。
sen.e: Therefore, some organizations overlapped, and on the other hand, there were many organizations which had plural Tang names for one organization.
Therefore, some organizations overlapped in using the Tang name; to the contrary, there were many cases in which a single organization had multiple Tang names.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: Therefore, some organizations overlapped in using the Tang name; to the contrary, there were many cases in which a single organization had multiple Tang names.

sen.j: 唐名は、除目における朝廷の正式な位記等に記されることこそは無かったが、書簡・日記・漢詩など私的な文書には頻繁に用いられた。
sen.e: Tang name was not used in a formal Iki (a letter of appointment) in Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) of Chotei (Imperial Court), however, often used in private documents such as letters, diaries, and Chinese-style poems.

Tang name was not used in a formal Iki (a letter of appointment) in Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) of Chotei (Imperial Court) and the like, however, often used in private documents such as letters, diaries, and Chinese-style poems.
sen.cmt: 表現の見直しをしました。
sen.e: Tang name was not used in a formal Iki (a letter of appointment) in Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) of Chotei (Imperial Court) and the like, however, often used in private documents such as letters, diaries, and Chinese-style poems.

sen.j: 江戸時代になってからも武家官位に付随する雅称として存続し、明治維新で律令制が名実ともに終焉を迎えた後も、明治初期の太政官制明治維新の太政官に付随して引き継がれた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Tang name was still continued as the elegant name attached to the Buke-kani (official court titles for samurai), and even after the ritsuryo system came to the end both in name and in reality by the Meiji restoration, it was took over by attaching to the System of Departments of State in the early Meiji era.
sen.cmt: 「明治初期の太政官制明治維新の太政官に」は「明治初期の太政官制に」の間違いと解釈して訳しました。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Tang name was still continued as the elegant name attached to the Buke-kani (official court titles for samurai), and even after the ritsuryo system came to the end both in name and in reality by the Meiji restoration, it was taken over by attaching to the System of Departments of State in the early Meiji era.

In the Edo period, Tang name was still continued as the elegant name attached to the Buke-kani (official court titles for samurai), and even after the ritsuryo system came to the end both in name and in reality by the Meiji restoration, it was taken over by attaching to the System of Departments of State in the early Meiji era.

sen.j: 明治18年（1885年）には内閣制度が発足するが、ここでも唐名の伝統は引き継がれ、内閣総理大臣を「首相」、外務大臣 (日本)を「外相」などと呼んだ。
sen.e: In 1885, the cabinet system was established, and even in this system, the tradition of Tang name was took over, so that the prime minister is called 'shusho' and the foreign minister is called 'gaisho.'

In 1885, the cabinet system was established, and even in this system, the tradition of Tang name was taken over, so that the prime minister was called 'shusho' and the foreign minister was called 'gaisho.'
sen.cmt: took overを taken overに変更、is をwasに変更（２箇所）しました。
sen.e: In 1885, the cabinet system was established, and even in this system, the tradition of Tang name was taken over, so that the prime minister was called 'shusho' and the foreign minister was called 'gaisho.'

sen.j: また内閣制度とともに設置された枢密院を「枢府」、枢密院議長を「枢相」、内大臣府と内大臣府をともに「内府」と呼ぶなど、この習慣は日本文化に完全に定着したものとなっている。
sen.e: Further, the Privy Council which was established together with the cabinet system was called 'sufu', the Chairman of the Privy Council was called 'susho', and both the Office of minister of the center and the minister of the center are called 'naifu', this custom is completely established in Japan.
sen.cmt: 「内大臣府と内大臣府をともに」は「内大臣府と内大臣をともに」の間違いと解釈して訳しました。
sen.e: Further, the Privy Council which was established together with the cabinet system was called 'sufu', the Chairman of the Privy Council was called 'susho', and both the Office of minister of the center and the minister of the center were called 'naifu', thus, this custom has been completely established in Japan.
sen.cmt: are called 'naifu' をwere called 'naifu' に変更, this custom is を thus, this custom has been に変更しました。。
sen.e: Further, the Privy Council which was established together with the cabinet system was called 'sufu', the Chairman of the Privy Council was called 'susho', and both the Office of minister of the center and the minister of the center were called 'naifu', thus, this custom has been completely established in Japan.

sen.j: 唐名で定着した歴史的名辞の例
sen.e: Examples of historic term fixed in Tang name

sen.e: The name used in "Sugawara Denju Tenarai Kagami" (Sugawara's secrets of calligraphy), the masterpiece of Joruri (Ballad drama) and Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors).

sen.e: The term comes from Shikibukyo of kyokkan (the most highest rank which one was appointed.)
